author: 8BrickMario
title: Dinosaur jokes! Yay.
review:
Ah, Dimensions. A good game that makes me buy things I don't want for the sake of completion. Oh, well. Is this better than my motivations?

Box/Instructions

The box art is pretty nice, and everything is shown off nicely. 

Parts

The parts here are pretty good, with the different shades of green on the Velociraptor and the printed gyrosphere dishes standing out. 

Minifigures

Owen Grady, one of the film's main characters, is a pretty nice figure, and no different from the one in the sets. His vest looks good, and the rest of his outfit is nicely detailed. 

The ACU is also decent, and while similar, doesn't exactly match any of the ACU troopers in the sets. His vest is nice, and his staff is a simple yet effective assembly. 

All being said, they're good accurate figures, but they both feel incredibly generic out of context. 

The build

The build is fairly straightforward. 

The completed model

The Velociraptor is a pretty nice model, and looks like it's supposed to. Its legs, arms, and head can be moved to pose it a bit, which is a plus. 

The Gyrosphere is speeding along a bumpy terrain (which I think is supposed to be a smooth ramp), and it looks pretty good. While they couldn't enclose it completely, the shape is conveyed nicely, and the blue streaks of speed are a nice touch. 

Gameplay

Owen's a useful character, if you read "useful" as "has an exclusive ability".  He is able to cut down long vines covering doorways or serving as walls with his knife. He is also able to track trails and use stealth by wearing a leaf cloak. His dialogue is best summed up as "Dinosaurs, dinosaurs, dinosaurs."

The ACU is a pretty basic character, with his main ability being to charge electric coils with his stun staff. His dialogue is all complaints about his job. 

The Velociraptor is a normal walker vehicle, and it serves as an alternative to Owen if you want to cut vines. Why is it that these abilities are always given in packs where the character included can do it just as well? It's just a sort of fake way to allow your other characters to solve the puzzles. 

The Gyrosphere is a necessary vehicle in the game, due to its unique ability to use gyrosphere switches recycled from LEGO Batman 2. The model conjures a full-sized gyrosphere in-game, which is good. Otherwise, it's a nice vehicle (can't jump, though) and it can be upgraded for sonar or greater speed. 

The Jurassic World is a nice adventure world, with the park and some of the scenery being included. Space isn't wasted, as some underground tunnels and laboratories are also available for exploration. It's definitely one of the more pretty worlds due to its natural scenery.

Overall opinion

I'm not quite sure if Jurassic World really fits with Dimensions. Its core concept is a bit of a fantastic stretch, but everything in it has a more realistic base and is less zany and weird than the other worlds and franchises in the game, making the sillier spin on the dialogue just seem stupid. That being said, the pack is pretty good and provides another step toward a complete Dimensions experience, so I'd recommend picking it up.

author: Odeinoichus
title: Journey through Dimensions with Dinosaurs.
review:
Set #71205 Jurassic World Team Pack: The first Team Pack to be reviewed is based on the previous LEGO Video Game that was released just before Dimensions, Jurassic World. Team Packs offer four toys for the price of 25$, unless you find them on sale or at discount outlets, the only real way to find most of these packs nowadays.

As a huge fan of LEGO Jurassic World it’s nice to see it included, but it is unfortunate that we couldn’t have had a Jurassic Park character included instead of a generic troop builder type character.

Packaging

As I have done with the Level Packs we shall discuss the Team Pack packaging in great detail with this first Team Pack review, and the rest of the Team Packs will comment briefly on changes for each Theme included in a Team Pack.

The boxes are pretty much the same as Level Pack boxes as far as the colours and overall design is concerned, the differences however is that these boxes have been widened so they can fit all four toys on the front and the small lip on the front which showcases the Level name has been removed so there is no yellow tag with a lock symbol to show what the pack unlocks.

We also lose some of the artwork on the packaging’s front and back, we don’t get to see any digital representations of the adventure world on Team Packs, which is unfortunate as it would have been nice to see an image like that on the box to be consistent with the other type of packs designs.

Parts

This set features a lot of green parts and some nice printed elements with the Gyrosphere design on some large clear dishes. It’d be a great set for parts if it didn’t cost so much, however if you find it on discount still it does have some nice parts.

Minifigures

ACU: A Minifigure we saw in the official Theme sets, the ACU only has a unique looking Toy Tag. With a nice blue paint job and the symbol of Jurassic World. I believe this character was also found in the Dilophosaurus set, the driver of the jeep.

Owen: This version of Owen is identical to the one found in the sets, he comes with a knife accessory and a unique toy tag that features the Jurassic World logo with some brown and silver markings.

The build

Velociraptor: The build for the Velociraptor is very straightforward and uses some nice parts, including the light green skeleton enemy arms. It’s a really nice and satisfying micro build.

Spike Attack Raptor: This build is practically the exact same as the main Raptor build, with a few minor changes to where the parts go so that the tail winds up with spikes on it, and the head looks more like a Parasaurolophus design.

Venom Raptor: I think this is an attempt to make a Dilophosaurus, but rather than just call it a Dilophosaurus, as the build is definitely more designed to resemble that species as seen in Jurassic Park, they’ve decided to turn it into a Venom Raptor. I guess this means that Raptors can shoot venom now… it’s a really odd design, but the build is relatively easy and fun looking, the colours even work as a Dilophosaurus.

Gyrosphere: The Gyropshere build is not entirely self-contained. It also doesn’t resemble the actual LEGO model while the in-game version does look like the actual physical model of this vehicle from the Theme. It’s a nice looking micro-build though that captures the look of the vehicle and some terrain as it travels along with it.

Sonic Beam Gyrosphere: This one alters the build to add some parts and make it resemble if it is housing some sonic cannons. This build changes the base, the rest of the build is also modified. It’s still fairly simple to follow along and build though.

Speed Boost Gyrosphere: Another modified build that changes the design of the base and where other parts sit on the main model… it’s really hard to discuss all of these because there is fairly little changed during the build process. It’s pretty simple and easy to follow along with though.

The completed model

Velociraptor & Alternate Models: All three of the Raptor models are very nicely constructed, though as I noted above the third build is more like a Dilophosaurus rather than a Velociraptor. Overall you can’t go wrong in any of these that you choose to build and display when playing with the physical models.

Gyrosphere & Alternate Models: These models are really not much different amongst themselves, and honestly I’m not sure which is the best one for display and play, but I do prefer the original model as it represents the vehicle much better than the Sonic Beam and Speed Boost variations mostly because it doesn’t have stupid add-ons to give the model physical weapons.

The Digital Content

Adventure World: There is no level unfortunately, but the Adventure World is quite nice. It’s basically a more self-contained version of what we saw in the LEGO Jurassic World video game, there aren’t as many locations, or dinosaurs roaming in the paddocks… at least in the PS3 version, I believe more dinosaurs become visible in the hub world on current gen consoles.

It features some nice musical tracks also and voice acting from many characters as you embark on quests to earn Gold Bricks. Overall a decent re-visit to the world we got to explore in LEGO Jurassic World.

Vehicle & Character Abilities: For Owen you can use Tracking, Stealth, Target and Vine Cut abilities while the ACU Trooper gives you the power to charge Electricity Switches and Illuminate dark areas.

The Gyrosphere is unique for Gyrosphere Switches, when you rebuild and upgrade it you can use Sonar Smash while driving it and the third upgrade let’s you Speed Boost into barricades.

The Velociraptor can also cut vines and grants the ability to dig once upgraded to the second form as well as destroy cracked LEGO objects, when you activate it in the menu it also has the ability to become a Guardian who will protect you during battles with enemies. The third build also has a Special Attack, when you aren’t using colour bolts anytime you hit the attack button it will do a unique attack instead and damage enemies that way.

Overall opinion

Unfortunately the characters are not unique in this set, both Minifigures are from the LEGO Jurassic World sets, the micro models however are truly unique and is one of only two ways of triggering Gyrosphere switches in game. So if you want to get everything done and accomplished in LEGO Dimensions you’ll definitely need to pick this set up.

The adventure world is really vast though and I do enjoy the overall look of the digital content. It’s also nice to hear Chris Pratt talking to himself as Owen and Emmet when both are the Toy Bad. Definitely recommended for fans of the game.
